prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a couple where the author is paying all the bills and their girlfriend only works part-time. There was an incident where the author forgot their wallet and asked the girlfriend to pay for takeout, which she was upset about. Now the author is considering making her start paying some bills because of this one incident.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The author has been covering all expenses, which might be a point of contention. The girlfriend's reaction was negative, which upset the author. The key issues here are financial contributions in a relationship and the author's response to a single incident.

In relationships, financial responsibilities can vary. Sometimes one partner earns more and takes on more expenses, but expectations can shift over time. The author is upset because the girlfriend reacted negatively, even though the takeout was a small amount. The author is now considering making her contribute more, perhaps out of principle. 

But is the author in the wrong? Well, the author hasn't contributed to the bills before. Suddenly changing the arrangement after a single incident might be seen as unfair. The girlfriend works part-time and may not have the means to contribute significantly. The author is using a $40 incident to justify a larger shift in responsibility. That might not be fair, especially if the girlfriend's income is limited. The author might be overreacting to a one-time event and using it as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement, which could be seen as using this incident as a pretext rather than addressing the underlying issue of shared responsibility.

Also, communication is a big part of relationships. The author doesn't mention discussing the financial contributions with the girlfriend before. Just because the author paid everything before doesn't mean the girlfriend isn't contributing in other ways. Maybe she handles other responsibilities or emotional labor. The author's unilateral decision to make her pay now could be seen as taking advantage of her part-time income without considering her circumstances.

So, the author's approach might be inconsiderate. Instead of addressing the issue calmly and discussing shared responsibilities, they are using a minor incident to enforce a change. That could be seen as the author being in the wrong because they're not considering the girlfriend's situation and are acting out of hurt pride rather than genuine need for shared financial responsibility.
